title: Using gp to wrangle plate data
text: work lab lab data, ’ve probably deal data look like : Just looking sucks. can use tidyverse magic use plater help least make matrix tidy data.frame, annotating wells rows columns can soul-rending (heavens forbid non-standard plate layout). vignette, ’ll tidy data, annotate fairly painless process.

title: Using gp to wrangle plate data
text: data shown represent absorbance values 562nm. gp lets us plot data quickly:  Allow describe ’re seeing. added benefit describing , also tidying - later. sample triplicate, triplicate stands next one another moving left right, wrapping around next ‘band’ rows hits edge. , simply:  However, wells sample , empty. want specify difference two:  Notice wrap = TRUE - allows sections bigger ‘parent section’ (plate) wrapping around next ‘band’. Now say want label one number triplicate - top sample 1, middle 2, bottom 3. sentence, mentioned ‘parent section’ section can also sections ’s . ’re going use idea label replicates:  Notice didn’t specify ncol. default, section take maximum space possible (19). Finally, want label sample name:  Now, fun part: Since described data well, tidying easy. First, supply data third argument gp: now use gp_serve: don’t know , think ’s pretty cool.
code: gp(8, 12, protein_quant) |>   gp_plot(value) gp(8, 12) |>    gp_sec("samples", nrow = 3, ncol = 1) |>    gp_plot(as.factor(samples)) +   ggplot2::theme(legend.position = "none") gp(8, 12) |>    gp_sec("has_sample", nrow = 3, ncol = 19, wrap = TRUE, labels = c("sample")) |>    gp_plot(has_sample) gp(8, 12) |>    gp_sec("has_sample", nrow = 3, ncol = 19, wrap = TRUE, labels = c("sample")) |>    gp_sec("replicate", nrow = 1, labels = c("1", "2", "3")) |>    gp_plot(replicate) gp(8, 12) |>    gp_sec("has_sample", nrow = 3, ncol = 19, wrap = TRUE, labels = c("sample")) |>    gp_sec("replicate", nrow = 1, labels = c("1", "2", "3")) |>    gp_sec("sample", nrow = 3, ncol = 1, labels = c(paste0("standard ", 1:7), paste0("sample ", 1:12))) |>    gp_plot(sample) +   ggplot2::theme(legend.position = "none") # Too many samples - clutters the plot my_plate <- gp(8, 12, protein_quant) |>    gp_sec("has_sample", nrow = 3, ncol = 19, wrap = TRUE, labels = c("sample")) |>    gp_sec("replicate", nrow = 1, labels = c("1", "2", "3")) |>    gp_sec("sample", nrow = 3, ncol = 1, labels = c(paste0("standard ", 1:7), paste0("sample ", 1:12))) gp_serve(my_plate) |>    dplyr::arrange(.row, .col) |>    head(20) |>    knitr::kable()

title: Making plots with gp
text: ’s often useful able plot microwell plate, either describe experiment performed visual manner, write documentation protocol. gp allows plot surprisingly diverse set layouts fairly simple syntax. Additionally, process plotting data used wrangle data (see vignette ‘Using gp wrangle plate data’). vignette teach plot plates.

title: Making plots with gp
text: basic element gp gp: ’s plate . instance, 6 well plate can created like : , ’m going omit argument names rows columns, like : Note plate standard format, can also just specify number wells : works standard plate layouts - listed : Note also specify wells = 96 MEAN 4x24 well plate, ’re going dissapointed. reason, ’s usually best explicit plate dimensions.
code: library(gp) six_well <- gp(rows = 2, cols = 3) six_well <- gp(2, 3) six_well <- gp(wells = 6) plate_formats |>    knitr::kable()

title: Making plots with gp
text: often helps plot gp build , section section (sections later). simple:  gp_plot takes two arguments: 1. gp object 2. name column gp$well_data like use color overlay plot Let’s dig point two second. gp list item buried within called well_data: seems like lot take , ’s really just data gp_plot plotting. second argument provide can one columns, provide additional columns start making sections (’s coming soon, promise!). (Note: want information columns, go ?gp) instance, can plot row number:  point also note axes arranged like plates - top left 1, 1.
code: my_plate <- gp(16, 24)  gp_plot(my_plate, .sec) my_plate$well_data |> head() #> # A tibble: 6 × 10 #>    .row  .col .sec_par  .sec .row_sec_par .row_sec .col_sec_par .col_sec #>   <int> <int>    <int> <int>        <int>    <int>        <int>    <int> #> 1     1     1        1     1            1        1            1        1 #> 2     1     2        1     1            1        1            2        2 #> 3     1     3        1     1            1        1            3        3 #> 4     1     4        1     1            1        1            4        4 #> 5     1     5        1     1            1        1            5        5 #> 6     1     6        1     1            1        1            6        6 #> # … with 2 more variables: .col_is_margin <lgl>, .row_is_margin <lgl> gp_plot(my_plate, .row)

title: Making plots with gp
text: package useless wasn’t ability add patterns plates. gp uses idea ‘sections’ can build ontop one another. ’ll make concrete examples, short plate biggest section, sections can sections. can sections us? Simply put, sections let us make rectangular patterns plates:  gp_sec workhorse gp. get fun stuff can , let’s go syntax. gp_sec takes several arguments: name. can refer later (gp_plot example ) Dimensions. default, dimension left blank tries fill maximum parent section (whole plate). done :  Note plot using condition. implies ’s part my_plate$well_data, since told ’s gp_plot gets plotting data , right? correct. make section, tack column named whatever named well_data. fundamental idea ‘tidying plot’ (, , gone ‘Using gp wrangle plate data’ vignette). ’s much cools stuff can gp_sec. Let’s go isolation.
code: my_plate |> gp_sec("condition", nrow = 16, ncol = 3) |>    gp_plot(as.factor(condition)) # To make sections a bit more visible my_plate |> gp_sec("condition", ncol = 3) |> gp_plot(as.factor(condition))

title: Making plots with gp
text: Starting gentle, can describe corner want section one supplying start_corner argument. default, start_corner = "tl". tl stands top-left, imagine can guess three options stand : tr, bl, br
code: my_plate |> gp_sec("condition", 8, 11) |> gp_plot(as.factor(condition)) my_plate |> gp_sec("condition", 8, 11, start_corner = "br") |> gp_plot(as.factor(condition))

what: Flowing - left/right first or top/bottom first?
title: Making plots with gp
text: Notice default next section side section . wanted next section /? can done simply setting flow either "row" "col":
code: my_plate |> gp_sec("condition", 8, 11, flow = "col") |> gp_plot(as.factor(condition))

title: Making plots with gp
text: Sometimes ’s nice bit space around sections. practical example, leave blank space around edge PCR plate avoid edge effects (poor seal, uneven lighting, etc). implement ?  Note specify dimensions . think get away just supplying name margin = 1, ’d unfortunately mistaken. mentioned previously, ncol nrow fill parent section. , margin gets ADDED . makes overflow parent (ie MARGIN PADDING, HTML/CSS inclined). Now can use fact sections can sections , say, show primers go:  Margins can also specified particular side supplying vector. works much CSS margin specification goes. One number: Applies margin four sides. Two numbers: First top bottom, second sides. Three numbers: First top, second sides, third bottom Four numbers: Top, right, bottom, left
code: borderless <- my_plate |> gp_sec("no_border", margin = 1, 14, 22)  borderless |> gp_plot(no_border) borderless |> gp_sec("primers", ncol = 3) |> gp_plot(as.factor(primers))

title: Making plots with gp
text: ’ll notice figure primer 8 isn’t full section. can omit might full section setting break_sections = FALSE:
code: borderless |>    gp_sec("primers", ncol = 3, break_sections = FALSE) |>    gp_plot(as.factor(primers))

title: Making plots with gp
text: Sometimes ’ll want wrap sections one clips edge, starts right back beginning next line. Like :  makes sense instances section big parent section. Without wrapping, wouldn’t able fit single full section plate.
code: my_plate |>    gp_sec("primers", nrow = 3, ncol = 27, wrap = TRUE) |>    gp_plot(as.factor(primers))

title: Making plots with gp
text: Labeling serves two purposes: Annotating section numbers, hiding sections don’t use (also third purpose, helps tidying - see vignette ).
code: my_plate |>    gp_sec("primers", ncol = 3, nrow = 7, labels = c("GBP2", "YAP1", "GAPDH")) |>    gp_plot(primers)

title: Making plots with gp
text: can make wild stuff just combining arguments together. Like :
code: gp(20, 20) |>    gp_sec("outer", 9, 7, margin = c(1, 0, 2, 1), start_corner = "br", wrap = TRUE, flow = "col") |>    gp_sec("inner", 2, 2, wrap = TRUE, start_corner = "tr", flow = "col") |>    gp_plot(as.factor(inner)) + ggplot2::theme(legend.position = "none")

title: Authors and Citation
text: Kai Aragaki. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Aragaki K (2022). gp: Grammar Plates. R package version 0.1.1, https://kaiaragaki.github.io/gp/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {gp: A Grammar of Plates},   author = {Kai Aragaki},   year = {2022},   note = {R package version 0.1.1},   url = {https://kaiaragaki.github.io/gp/}, }

title: A Grammar of Plates
text: gp introduces grammar plates. Microwell plates usually arranged visually meaningful ways tidy data, manipulation tidy form cumbersome. gp aimed developers create packages ingest produce plate data well interactive operating microwell data.

title: A Grammar of Plates
text: can install development version GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("KaiAragaki/gp")

title: A Grammar of Plates
text: Creating plate plot simple: can add rectangular ‘sections’ plates:  sections can sections , just layering one gp_sec .  gp also theme - gp_mini_theme - lets create sparkline-esque plates. instance: align primers columns  instead rows
code: library(gp) gp(rows = 16, cols = 24) |>   gp_plot(as.factor(.row)) gp(rows = 16, cols = 24) |>    gp_sec("my_section", nrow = 12, ncol = 6) |>    gp_plot(as.factor(my_section)) gp(rows = 16, cols = 24) |>    gp_sec("my_section", nrow = 12, ncol = 6) |>    gp_sec("secsec", nrow = 3, ncol = 3) |>    gp_plot(as.factor(secsec)) mini_plot_cols <- gp(8, 12) |>    gp_sec(name = "primers", ncol = 3) |>    gp_plot(as.factor(primers)) +    gp_mini_theme() ggplot2::ggsave(filename = "./man/figures/mini-plot_cols.png",                  plot = mini_plot_cols,                 height = 0.5,                  width = 0.75,                  units = "in",                  scale = 3.5)  mini_plot_rows <- gp(8, 12) |>    gp_sec(name = "primers", nrow = 3) |>    gp_plot(as.factor(primers)) +    gp_mini_theme() ggplot2::ggsave(filename = "./man/figures/mini-plot_rows.png",                  plot = mini_plot_rows,                 height = 0.5,                  width = 0.75,                  units = "in",                  scale = 3.5)

what: Arrange gp well data relative to user supplied start_corner — arrange_by_dim
title: Arrange gp well data relative to user supplied start_corner — arrange_by_dim
text: Arrange gp well data relative user supplied start_corner

title: Arrange gp well data relative to user supplied start_corner — arrange_by_dim
code: arrange_by_dim(gp, dim)

title: Arrange gp well data relative to user supplied start_corner — arrange_by_dim
text: gp gp object dim Character. Either "row" "col"

title: Arrange gp well data relative to user supplied start_corner — arrange_by_dim
text: gp gp$well_data arranged dim non-dim (ie dim = "row", 'non-dim' "col") relative start corner (start corner top, farther start corner bottom)

title: Coerce object to gp — as_gp
text: x Object coerce ... Unused

title: Create a dimension pattern 'unit' of a section — coordinate
text: Create dimension pattern 'unit' section

title: Create a dimension pattern 'unit' of a section — coordinate
code: coordinate(gp, type = c("row", "col"), margin)

title: Create a dimension pattern 'unit' of a section — coordinate
text: gp gp type Character. Either 'row' 'col'. margin Named list integers defining size margins edge.

text: tibble

what: A 8x12 matrix of random integers 1-10 — example_plate

title: Make a gp object — gp
text: Make gp object

title: Make a gp object — gp
code: gp(rows = NULL, cols = NULL, data = NULL, wells = NULL, tidy = FALSE)

title: Make a gp object — gp
text: rows Numeric. number rows plate . cols Numeric. number columns plate . data optional data.frame well data dimensions plate described wells Numeric. number wells plate . specified, rows cols must null - inferred common form factors plates. tidy data supplied tidy?

title: Make a gp object — gp
text: gp object

title: Make a gp object — gp
text: gp object following components: nrow/ncol: Number plate rows/cols. static changed adding layers. well_data: Somewhat transient data used define plotting coordinates layers. See information. nrow_sec/ncols_sec: number rows/cols current section. creating plate, number number rows/cols plate (plate section). Can take 'mar' suffix, specifies number including margins () nrow_sec_par/ncol_sec_par: number rows/cols parent section. creating plate, parent, defaults parent. Can take 'mar' suffix. See . well_data consists many columns. variable names can broken follows: row/col: row always y axis, col always x axis. convention, plates start 1, 1 top left corner. sec: Short 'section'. section rectangular field wells. sec alone refers number section . sec combined row col (eg row_sec) refers coordinates given well relative section corners, top left corner given section always (1, 1). par: Short 'parent'. columns data previous layer. index: specify (usually) multiwell strips defined one dimension. Together, index_row index_col form checkerboard-like patterns, intersection section. bit complicated wrap = TRUE, simile hold cases.

title: Make a gp object — gp
code: # If you specify wells, rows and columns are derived from a standard plate sizes:  gp(wells = 96) #> $nrow #> [1] 8 #>  #> $ncol #> [1] 12 #>  #> $well_data #> # A tibble: 96 × 10 #>     .row  .col .sec_par  .sec .row_sec_par .row_sec .col_sec_par .col_sec #>    <int> <int>    <int> <int>        <int>    <int>        <int>    <int> #>  1     1     1        1     1            1        1            1        1 #>  2     1     2        1     1            1        1            2        2 #>  3     1     3        1     1            1        1            3        3 #>  4     1     4        1     1            1        1            4        4 #>  5     1     5        1     1            1        1            5        5 #>  6     1     6        1     1            1        1            6        6 #>  7     1     7        1     1            1        1            7        7 #>  8     1     8        1     1            1        1            8        8 #>  9     1     9        1     1            1        1            9        9 #> 10     1    10        1     1            1        1           10       10 #> # … with 86 more rows, and 2 more variables: .col_is_margin <lgl>, #> #   .row_is_margin <lgl> #>  #> $start_corner #> [1] "tl" #>  #> $start_corner_par #> [1] "tl" #>  #> $nrow_sec #> [1] 8 #>  #> $nrow_sec_mar #> [1] 8 #>  #> $nrow_sec_par #> [1] 8 #>  #> $nrow_sec_par_mar #> [1] 8 #>  #> $ncol_sec #> [1] 12 #>  #> $ncol_sec_mar #> [1] 12 #>  #> $ncol_sec_par #> [1] 12 #>  #> $ncol_sec_par_mar #> [1] 12 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gp"  # As such, you cannot use the wells argument if you want to create more exotic plates:  try(gp(wells = 102)) #> Error in gp(wells = 102) :  #>   wells is not of a known format (6, 12, 24, 48, 96, 384, 1536, or 3456)  # For that, you'll need to specify wells and cols:  gp(rows = 6, cols = 17) #> $nrow #> [1] 6 #>  #> $ncol #> [1] 17 #>  #> $well_data #> # A tibble: 102 × 10 #>     .row  .col .sec_par  .sec .row_sec_par .row_sec .col_sec_par .col_sec #>    <int> <int>    <int> <int>        <int>    <int>        <int>    <int> #>  1     1     1        1     1            1        1            1        1 #>  2     1     2        1     1            1        1            2        2 #>  3     1     3        1     1            1        1            3        3 #>  4     1     4        1     1            1        1            4        4 #>  5     1     5        1     1            1        1            5        5 #>  6     1     6        1     1            1        1            6        6 #>  7     1     7        1     1            1        1            7        7 #>  8     1     8        1     1            1        1            8        8 #>  9     1     9        1     1            1        1            9        9 #> 10     1    10        1     1            1        1           10       10 #> # … with 92 more rows, and 2 more variables: .col_is_margin <lgl>, #> #   .row_is_margin <lgl> #>  #> $start_corner #> [1] "tl" #>  #> $start_corner_par #> [1] "tl" #>  #> $nrow_sec #> [1] 6 #>  #> $nrow_sec_mar #> [1] 6 #>  #> $nrow_sec_par #> [1] 6 #>  #> $nrow_sec_par_mar #> [1] 6 #>  #> $ncol_sec #> [1] 17 #>  #> $ncol_sec_mar #> [1] 17 #>  #> $ncol_sec_par #> [1] 17 #>  #> $ncol_sec_par_mar #> [1] 17 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gp"

what: Add a section to a gp object. — gp_sec
title: Add a section to a gp object. — gp_sec
text: Add section gp object.

title: Add a section to a gp object. — gp_sec
code: gp_sec(   gp,   name,   nrow = NULL,   ncol = NULL,   labels = NULL,   start_corner = c("tl", "tr", "bl", "br"),   flow = c("row", "col"),   margin = 0,   wrap = FALSE,   break_sections = TRUE )

title: Add a section to a gp object. — gp_sec
text: gp gp object name Character. Name section. nrow Numeric. Section height. NULL, fill width parent section. ncol Numeric. Section width. NULL, fill width parent section. labels Optional. labels section ? start_corner Corner section place first item. flow Direction subsequent items placed relative first corner. margin Border width outside section unfilled. Can take argument one (border around), two (top/bottom, left/right), three (top, left/right, bottom), four (top, right, bottom, left). wrap sections go edge continue next row/column? break_sections partial sections allowed?

title: Add a section to a gp object. — gp_sec
text: gp

title: Add a section to a gp object. — gp_sec
code: gp(16, 24) |> gp_sec("section 1", ncol = 3) #> $nrow #> [1] 16 #>  #> $ncol #> [1] 24 #>  #> $well_data #> # A tibble: 384 × 15 #>    .row_sec_par .col_map_sec .col_is_margin .col_sec .col_sec_rel .col_sec_par #>           <int> <chr>        <lgl>             <int>        <int>        <int> #>  1            1 1            FALSE                 1            1            1 #>  2            1 1            FALSE                 2            2            2 #>  3            1 1            FALSE                 3            3            3 #>  4            2 1            FALSE                 1            1            1 #>  5            2 1            FALSE                 2            2            2 #>  6            2 1            FALSE                 3            3            3 #>  7            3 1            FALSE                 1            1            1 #>  8            3 1            FALSE                 2            2            2 #>  9            3 1            FALSE                 3            3            3 #> 10            4 1            FALSE                 1            1            1 #> # … with 374 more rows, and 9 more variables: .row_map_sec <chr>, #> #   .row_is_margin <lgl>, .row_sec <int>, .row_sec_rel <int>, .row <int>, #> #   .col <int>, .sec_par <int>, .sec <int>, `section 1` <int> #>  #> $start_corner #> [1] "tl" #>  #> $start_corner_par #> [1] "tl" #>  #> $nrow_sec #> [1] 16 #>  #> $nrow_sec_mar #> [1] 16 #>  #> $nrow_sec_par #> [1] 16 #>  #> $nrow_sec_par_mar #> [1] 16 #>  #> $ncol_sec #> [1] 3 #>  #> $ncol_sec_mar #> [1] 3 #>  #> $ncol_sec_par #> [1] 24 #>  #> $ncol_sec_par_mar #> [1] 24 #>  #> $row_unit #> # A tibble: 16 × 4 #>    .row_map_sec .row_is_margin .row_sec .row_sec_rel #>    <chr>        <lgl>             <int>        <int> #>  1 1            FALSE                 1            1 #>  2 1            FALSE                 2            2 #>  3 1            FALSE                 3            3 #>  4 1            FALSE                 4            4 #>  5 1            FALSE                 5            5 #>  6 1            FALSE                 6            6 #>  7 1            FALSE                 7            7 #>  8 1            FALSE                 8            8 #>  9 1            FALSE                 9            9 #> 10 1            FALSE                10           10 #> 11 1            FALSE                11           11 #> 12 1            FALSE                12           12 #> 13 1            FALSE                13           13 #> 14 1            FALSE                14           14 #> 15 1            FALSE                15           15 #> 16 1            FALSE                16           16 #>  #> $col_unit #> # A tibble: 3 × 4 #>   .col_map_sec .col_is_margin .col_sec .col_sec_rel #>   <chr>        <lgl>             <int>        <int> #> 1 1            FALSE                 1            1 #> 2 1            FALSE                 2            2 #> 3 1            FALSE                 3            3 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "gp"
